names.h

00001 /*
00002  * Names.h - names and types used by ascmagic in file(1).
00003  * These tokens are here because they can appear anywhere in
00004  * the first HOWMANY bytes, while tokens in /etc/magic must
00005  * appear at fixed offsets into the file. Don't make HOWMANY
00006  * too high unless you have a very fast CPU.
00007  *
00008  * Copyright (c) Ian F. Darwin, 1987.
00009  * Written by Ian F. Darwin.
00010  *
00011  * See LEGAL.NOTICE
00012  *
00013  * $Id: names.h,v 1.18 2000/08/05 17:36:49 christos Exp $
00014  */
00015 
00016 /*
00017     modified by Chris Lowth - 9 April 2000
00018     to add mime type strings to the types table.
00019 */
00020 
00021 /* these types are used to index the table 'types': keep em in sync! */
00022 #define L_C 0       /* first and foremost on UNIX */
00023 #define L_CC    1       /* Bjarne's postincrement */
00024 #define L_FORT  2       /* the oldest one */
00025 #define L_MAKE  3       /* Makefiles */
00026 #define L_PLI   4       /* PL/1 */
00027 #define L_MACH  5       /* some kinda assembler */
00028 #define L_ENG   6       /* English */
00029 #define L_PAS   7       /* Pascal */
00030 #define L_MAIL  8       /* Electronic mail */
00031 #define L_NEWS  9       /* Usenet Netnews */
00032 #define L_JAVA  10      /* Java code */
00033 #define L_HTML  11      /* HTML */
00034 #define L_BCPL  12      /* BCPL */
00035 #define L_M4    13      /* M4 */
00036 
00037 static const struct {
00038     char *human;
00039     char *mime;
00040 } types[] = {
00041     { "C program",                  "text/x-c", },
00042     { "C++ program",                "text/x-c++" },
00043     { "FORTRAN program",                "text/x-fortran" },
00044     { "make commands",              "text/x-makefile" },
00045     { "PL/1 program",               "text/x-pl1" },
00046     { "assembler program",              "text/x-asm" },
00047     { "English",                    "text/plain, English" },
00048     { "Pascal program",             "text/x-pascal" },
00049     { "mail",                   "text/x-mail" },
00050     { "news",                   "text/x-news" },
00051     { "Java program",               "text/x-java" },
00052     { "HTML document",              "text/html", },
00053     { "BCPL program",               "text/x-bcpl" },
00054     { "M4 macro language pre-processor",        "text/x-m4" },
00055     { "can't happen error on names.h/types",    "error/x-error" },
00056     { 0, 0}
00057 };
00058 
00059 /*
00060  * XXX - how should we distinguish Java from C++?
00061  * The trick used in a Debian snapshot, of having "extends" or "implements"
00062  * as tags for Java, doesn't work very well, given that those keywords
00063  * are often preceded by "class", which flags it as C++.
00064  *
00065  * Perhaps we need to be able to say
00066  *
00067  *  If "class" then
00068  *
00069  *      if "extends" or "implements" then
00070  *          Java
00071  *      else
00072  *          C++
00073  *  endif
00074  *
00075  * Or should we use other keywords, such as "package" or "import"?
00076  * Unfortunately, Ada95 uses "package", and Modula-3 uses "import",
00077  * although I infer from the language spec at
00078  *
00079  *  http://www.research.digital.com/SRC/m3defn/html/m3.html
00080  *
00081  * that Modula-3 uses "IMPORT" rather than "import", i.e. it must be
00082  * in all caps.
00083  *
00084  * So, for now, we go with "import".  We must put it before the C++
00085  * stuff, so that we don't misidentify Java as C++.  Not using "package"
00086  * means we won't identify stuff that defines a package but imports
00087  * nothing; hopefully, very little Java code imports nothing (one of the
00088  * reasons for doing OO programming is to import as much as possible
00089  * and write only what you need to, right?).
00090  *
00091  * Unfortunately, "import" may cause us to misidentify English text
00092  * as Java, as it comes after "the" and "The".  Perhaps we need a fancier
00093  * heuristic to identify Java?
00094  */
00095 static struct names {
00096     const char *name;
00097     short type;
00098 } names[] = {
00099     /* These must be sorted by eye for optimal hit rate */
00100     /* Add to this list only after substantial meditation */
00101     {"dnl",     L_M4},
00102     {"import",  L_JAVA},
00103     {"\"libhdr\"",  L_BCPL},
00104     {"\"LIBHDR\"",  L_BCPL},
00105     {"//",      L_CC},
00106     {"template",    L_CC},
00107     {"virtual", L_CC},
00108     {"class",   L_CC},
00109     {"public:", L_CC},
00110     {"private:",    L_CC},
00111     {"/*",      L_C},   /* must precede "The", "the", etc. */
00112     {"#include",    L_C},
00113     {"char",    L_C},
00114     {"The",     L_ENG},
00115     {"the",     L_ENG},
00116     {"double",  L_C},
00117     {"extern",  L_C},
00118     {"float",   L_C},
00119     {"struct",  L_C},
00120     {"union",   L_C},
00121     {"CFLAGS",  L_MAKE},
00122     {"LDFLAGS", L_MAKE},
00123     {"all:",    L_MAKE},
00124     {".PRECIOUS",   L_MAKE},
00125 /* Too many files of text have these words in them.  Find another way
00126  * to recognize Fortrash.
00127  */
00128 #ifdef  NOTDEF
00129     {"subroutine",  L_FORT},
00130     {"function",    L_FORT},
00131     {"block",   L_FORT},
00132     {"common",  L_FORT},
00133     {"dimension",   L_FORT},
00134     {"integer", L_FORT},
00135     {"data",    L_FORT},
00136 #endif  /*NOTDEF*/
00137     {".ascii",  L_MACH},
00138     {".asciiz", L_MACH},
00139     {".byte",   L_MACH},
00140     {".even",   L_MACH},
00141     {".globl",  L_MACH},
00142     {".text",   L_MACH},
00143     {"clr",     L_MACH},
00144     {"(input,", L_PAS},
00145     {"dcl",     L_PLI},
00146     {"Received:",   L_MAIL},
00147     {">From",   L_MAIL},
00148     {"Return-Path:",L_MAIL},
00149     {"Cc:",     L_MAIL},
00150     {"Newsgroups:", L_NEWS},
00151     {"Path:",   L_NEWS},
00152     {"Organization:",L_NEWS},
00153     {"href=",   L_HTML},
00154     {"HREF=",   L_HTML},
00155     {"<body",   L_HTML},
00156     {"<BODY",   L_HTML},
00157     {NULL,      0}
00158 };
00159 #define NNAMES ((sizeof(names)/sizeof(struct names)) - 1)
